texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: /2014/08/22/asus-maximus-vi-gene-error-55/
texts.text: /2014/08/22/asus-maximus-vi-gene-error-55/

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: asus
texts.text: asus

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: fedora
texts.text: fedora

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: hardware
texts.text: hardware

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It's been quite a while since I built a computer but I decided to give it a try for a new hypervisor/NAS box at home. I picked up an  Asus Maximus VI Gene  motherboard since it had some good parts installed and it seems to work well with Linux. This was my first time doing water cooling for the CPU and I picked up a  Seidon 240M  after getting some recommendations.
texts.text: It's been quite a while since I built a computer but I decided to give it a try for a new hypervisor/NAS box at home. I picked up an  Asus Maximus VI Gene  motherboard since it had some good parts installed and it seems to work well with Linux. This was my first time doing water cooling for the CPU and I picked up a  Seidon 240M  after getting some recommendations.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Rubber hits the road
texts.text: Rubber hits the road

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Once everything was in the box and the power was applied, I was stuck with an error code. There's a two-digit LCD display on the motherboard that rapidly flips between different codes during boot-up. If it stays on a code for a while and you don't get any display output, you have a problem. For me, this Asus Q code was 55.
texts.text: Once everything was in the box and the power was applied, I was stuck with an error code. There's a two-digit LCD display on the motherboard that rapidly flips between different codes during boot-up. If it stays on a code for a while and you don't get any display output, you have a problem. For me, this Asus Q code was 55.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The manual says it means that RAM isn't installed. I pulled out my four sticks of RAM and reseated all of them. I still got the same error. After reading a bunch of forum posts, I ran through a lot of troubleshooting steps:
texts.text: The manual says it means that RAM isn't installed. I pulled out my four sticks of RAM and reseated all of them. I still got the same error. After reading a bunch of forum posts, I ran through a lot of troubleshooting steps:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Reseat the RAM
texts.text: Reseat the RAM

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Try one stick of RAM and add more until the error comes back
texts.text: Try one stick of RAM and add more until the error comes back

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Reseat the CPU cooler (at least three times)
texts.text: Reseat the CPU cooler (at least three times)

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Reseat the CPU (at least three times)
texts.text: Reseat the CPU (at least three times)

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Upgrade the BIOS
texts.text: Upgrade the BIOS

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Clear the CMOS
texts.text: Clear the CMOS

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Curse loudly,
texts.text: Curse loudly,

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I still had error 55 and wasn't going anywhere fast. After some further testing, I found that if I left the two RAM slots next to the CPU empty, the system would boot. If I put any RAM in the two left RAM slots (A1 and A2), the system wouldn't boot. Here's an excerpt from the manual:
texts.text: I still had error 55 and wasn't going anywhere fast. After some further testing, I found that if I left the two RAM slots next to the CPU empty, the system would boot. If I put any RAM in the two left RAM slots (A1 and A2), the system wouldn't boot. Here's an excerpt from the manual:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: mobo_schematic CPU is on the left. RAM slots are A1, A2, B1, B2, left to right.
texts.text: mobo_schematic CPU is on the left. RAM slots are A1, A2, B1, B2, left to right.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Fine-tuning the Google search
texts.text: Fine-tuning the Google search

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I adjusted my Google terms to include "A1 A2 slots" and found more posts talking about CPU coolers being installed incorrectly. Mine had to be correct - I installed it four times! I decided to try re-installing it one last time.
texts.text: I adjusted my Google terms to include "A1 A2 slots" and found more posts talking about CPU coolers being installed incorrectly. Mine had to be correct - I installed it four times! I decided to try re-installing it one last time.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: When I removed the CPU cooler from the CPU, I noticed something strange. There are four standoffs around the CPU that the cooler would attach to with screws. Those standoffs screwed into posts that connected to a bracket on the back of the motherboard.
texts.text: When I removed the CPU cooler from the CPU, I noticed something strange. There are four standoffs around the CPU that the cooler would attach to with screws. Those standoffs screwed into posts that connected to a bracket on the back of the motherboard.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: standoffs  The lower two standoffs are highlighted.
texts.text: standoffs  The lower two standoffs are highlighted.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I removed the two standoffs that were closest to the A1/A2 RAM slots and noticed something peculiar. One side of the standoff had a black coating that seemed a bit tacky while the other side of the standoff was bare metal. Three of the standoffs had the black side down (against the board) while one had the black side up. I unscrewed that standoff and found that the bare metal side was wedged firmly onto some connections that run from the CPU to the A1/A2 RAM slots.  Could this be the issue?
texts.text: I removed the two standoffs that were closest to the A1/A2 RAM slots and noticed something peculiar. One side of the standoff had a black coating that seemed a bit tacky while the other side of the standoff was bare metal. Three of the standoffs had the black side down (against the board) while one had the black side up. I unscrewed that standoff and found that the bare metal side was wedged firmly onto some connections that run from the CPU to the A1/A2 RAM slots.  Could this be the issue?

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Eureka
texts.text: Eureka

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: After double-checking all of the CPU cooler standoffs and attaching the cooler to the board, I crossed my fingers and hit the power button. The machine shot through POST and I was staring down a Fedora logo that quickly led to a GDM login.
texts.text: After double-checking all of the CPU cooler standoffs and attaching the cooler to the board, I crossed my fingers and hit the power button. The machine shot through POST and I was staring down a Fedora logo that quickly led to a GDM login.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: culprit  The culprit
texts.text: culprit  The culprit

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I don't talk about hardware too often on the blog, but I certainly hopes this helps someone else who is desperately trying to find a solution.
texts.text: I don't talk about hardware too often on the blog, but I certainly hopes this helps someone else who is desperately trying to find a solution.
